learning_outcomes.description: Students will analyse news topics and write a news story.
Students will observe, investigate and gather information for a news story.
Students will learn to pitch a news story in the appropriate format to a news editor.
Students will identify news sources and interview them for publication.
Students will learn to exercise their ethical judgement to report in a fair, balanced and accurate manner.
Students will create a contemporary multimedia news story in the appropriate style and structure.

assessments.task_description:
You will write two news leads based on information provided in hard copy at the beginning of the assessment. Each lead must capture the central news value of its story with clarity and precision, demonstrating your ability to identify the strongest angle under time pressure.

This is a handwritten task. You will compose both leads during the invigilated assessment period using the material supplied on the day. Electronic devices are not permitted unless prior approval has been granted by the course coordinator.

Your work must comply with the SCA Style Guide, including spelling, punctuation, syntax and grammar. Failure to meet these style requirements may result in a zero grade for this task.

This assessment evaluates your ability to produce accurate, original work without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). The use of such technologies is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.assessment_title: News Story Pitch and Story Brief
assessments.category: Paper/ Report/ Annotation, Notebook/ Logbook, Project
assessments.task_description:
Pitch (your story idea + rationale to editor) - 250 – 350 words - 15% of 30

Submit a pitch for one hyperlocal news story, written in the first person and directed to the editor of your nominated local news outlet. Your pitch should clearly communicate the story idea, why it matters now, and why your audience will care. Treat it as a real professional pitch: concise, purposeful, and grounded in evidence.

Your story idea must be original and based on a genuine issue, event, or development within your local community. You must propose at least two primary sources - real people you can contact and interview for Assessment 3. Family members are not permitted. You are encouraged to make initial contact or attempt a short pre-interview where appropriate.

You must include a preliminary contact list for your nominated sources (names, roles, and contact details) in your brief. This demonstrates that your reporting plans are feasible and that your sources are accessible.

Your pitch should address:

  • Your angle: what the story is really about and why it matters.
  • Newsworthiness: why this is a news story, and what it offers your outlet’s audience.
  • Core facts: the who, what, when, where, why, and how.
  • Your proposed primary sources and why they are the right voices for this story.
  • Relevant secondary material (e.g., public data, statements, reports, online sources). NOT other news stories.

You will develop this same idea into a full news story for Assessment 3. Read the Assessment 3 description to ensure you pitch something workable, timely, and reportable.

Use of AI:

Generative AI is permitted in the development of your written pitch as a writing tool, not as a substitute for editorial judgment. The story itself must originate from your own reporting idea, and all sources must be real people you are able to contact and interview. AI cannot be used to invent sources, quotes, events, or any form of fabricated material. Misuse will be treated as academic misconduct and a fail.

 

Story Brief – 350 – 450 words - 15% of 30

Alongside your pitch, you will submit a detailed story brief compiled as one .pdf file. The purpose of the brief is to demonstrate the depth of your research, the logic behind your angle, and the practical steps you will take to report the story. This document mirrors the briefing notes used by professional journalists and producers when preparing a reporter or presenter for a story. It should stand on its own, clear enough that another journalist could pick it up and understand your rationale, the story context, the sources, and the reporting plan.

Your brief should include:

  • Context and significance: What is the wider issue or development your story sits within? Why does it matter now?
  • Background research: Key facts, recent updates, relevant data, policy, or history that shape the story.
  • Stakeholder map: The individuals, groups, or institutions affected by or involved in the story.
  • Primary sources:
  • Who they are
  • Why they matter
  • What perspectives or information you expect from them
  • Evidence that you can access them (contact details, emails, phone calls, visit attempts, etc.)
  • Interview strategy:
  • Key questions or themes you intend to explore
  • Anticipated lines of inquiry
  • Any ethical considerations or sensitivities
  • Verification plan: How you intend to check claims, confirm facts, and address conflicting accounts.
  • Reporting plan: When and how you intend to complete interviews, gather multimedia elements, and produce your final story.
  • Potential risks/constraints: Access issues, legal considerations, safety concerns, or reporting obstacles you may need to navigate.
  • Proposed story structure (early draft): How you currently imagine your story unfolding, your likely lead, key moments, and narrative shape.

The brief must be written in professional, third-person voice. It is not part of the pitch and will be assessed as a separate component of Assessment 2.

Use of AI:

Students may use AI as part of their writing and planning process, but the brief must reflect your own research, reporting initiative, and editorial judgment. AI must not be used to create fictitious facts, sources, quotes, or events.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Final News Story: Story, Images and Video
assessments.task_description:
Assessment 3 — Final News Story, Images and Video (500–650 words), 50%

Produce a hyperlocal news story about an event or issue in the community where you live. Your story may be written in news or feature style, but it must follow professional journalistic conventions and demonstrate depth, accuracy, and strong news judgment. The story should be 500–650 words and must be grounded in original reporting.

Your written story must include a minimum of three primary sources whom you have interviewed for this assessment. You may draw on any number of secondary sources - public data, media statements, documents, online material, provided they are used responsibly and clearly attributed within the story. Academic referencing is not permitted; all attribution must follow journalistic style.

Your accompanying two images should strengthen the story visually and be suitable for publication alongside the piece in the news outlet you identified in Assessment 2. Each photograph must include a caption with accurate identification of people and relevant context. Captions are not included in the word count.

You will also produce a 30–45 second video summary or a supporting angle of your story designed for social media distribution. This should be in a format appropriate for TikTok or Instagram Reels and should match the tone and style of your nominated outlet. The video does not need to feature the sources interviewed for the written story (but if appropriate and you've secured their consent, then it may include those sources); it may be a piece-to-camera or an edited visual explainer. It must, however, communicate the core of your story clearly and professionally. Upload the video file to Turnitin or as instructed on Blackboard. Parody or satire is not permitted.

Submit an appendix containing:

  • A contact list for all primary sources interviewed, including details of how contact was made.
  • A reference list of secondary sources (hyperlinks only), providing clear, accessible documentation of all supporting material. Academic referencing formats are not required.

Use of AI:

Generative AI may be used for limited purposes such as proofreading, clarifying expression, or testing structural ideas. It must not be used to fabricate events, sources, quotes, or reporting. The story must reflect your own journalistic decision-making, voice, and reporting practice. Misuse of AI including invented evidence or synthetic interviews will be treated as academic misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit via Blackboard. Students are permitted to submit their story in another media platform (eg. sound, vision) if they obtain prior approval from their tutor or course coordinator.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.
